description: A fox-hunting term, said to be from the note of a hunting horn.

examples: Fryar John began to paw, neigh and whinny at the Snout's end, as one ready to leap, or at least to play the Ass, and get up and ride tantivy to the Devil like a Beggar on Horseback.
Sir , I expected to hear from you in the Language of the lost Groat , and the Prodigal Son , and not in such a Tantivy of Language

entries.meaning: (informal) The sound of a hunting horn in imitation of a galloping horse
examples: Jack then placed himself on the opposite side of the pit, farthest from the giantâ€™s lodging, and, just at the break of day, he put the horn to his mouth, and blew, Tantivy, Tantivy. This noise roused the giant.

verbs.description: tantivy (third-person singular simple present tantivies, present participle tantivying, simple past and past participle tantivied)
